titleStmt.title: An ansvver to the declaration of the imaginary Parliament of the unknowne Common-wealth of England, concerning the affaires past betwixt them of England, and the high and mighty lords the States Generall of the United Provinces: wherein their frivolous reasons are cleerly refuted; and their injust proceedings in the treaty of the aforesaid affaires, as in all their actions, manifestly discovered.

titleStmt.title: An ansvver to the declaration of the imaginary Parliament of the unknowne Common-wealth of England, concerning the affaires past betwixt them of England, and the high and mighty lords the States Generall of the United Provinces: wherein their frivolous reasons are cleerly refuted; and their injust proceedings in the treaty of the aforesaid affaires, as in all their actions, manifestly discovered.

notesStmt.note: A reply to a Parliamentary declaration dated 7 Sept. 1652.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ANSWER TO THE DECLARATION Of the Imaginary Parliament of the unknowne Common-wealth of England, concerning the Affaires pa≈øt betwixt Them of England, and the High and Mighty Lords the States Generall of the United Provinces: Wherein their Frivolous Rea≈øons are cleerly refuted; and their inju≈øt proceedings in the Treaty of the afore≈øaid Affaires, as in all their Actions, Manife≈øtly di≈øcovered.

THe Authors of this Declaration are the ≈øame men; who having acted that execrable parricide upon the King a≈ø≈øumed the name of Parliament, which they had aboli≈øhed. Their beginning and growth hath beene formerly publi≈øhed, how a few lurking Sectaries being at fir≈øt Members of Parliament, and con≈øorting in prodigious opinions in Religion and policy with the illiterate rabble, became u≈øefull to the prime projectors, that under the maske of ≈øecuring Religion and Lawes, ≈øought to gaine the power of the State into their hands, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted in their votes in the Lower Hou≈øe, and applauded abroad for their proceedings by this bu≈øy crew, who got into places in the Army, and at la≈øt gave law to their old Ma≈øters, and having renounced faith and obedience to their King, with more ea≈øe ≈øcorned the bonds of a≈ø≈øociation to their guides & con≈øorts in the ≈øame impieties; And it cannot ≈øeem ≈øtrange to any that look on their Actions, to reade their ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe Declarations, nor that they ≈øhould proceede with like injury to ≈øtrangers, as they have u≈øed to their King, Companions and Countreymen.

They ≈øay, the returns which the people of the ∆≤nited Provinces, made toward this Commonwealth will hardly be believed, if their ≈øufferings and deliverance, and the principles and spirit that acted in them then be remembred, and the help they had from this Nation with the expence of Engli≈øh blood and trea≈øure. The people of the≈øe Provinces have with gratitude acknowledged the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance they received from the Crown of England, and the affection and readines of the Engli≈øh Nation; And it were a ju≈øt reproach if they ≈øhould make returnes for tho≈øe benefits to the U≈øurpers of the regal power, de≈øtroyers of the Monarchy, and Oppre≈ø≈øors of this Nation. Can Nationall obligations be transferred to the Enemies of the Nation? And becau≈øe a Traiterous Army hath gotten power over the Nation, ≈øhall the Friends and Allies of the Nation a≈ø≈øi≈øt the U≈øurpers? This will hardly be believed, but ea≈øily that the≈øe Declarers have the impudence to pretend a right to all that which was due to the Crown that they have abjured.

Though their boa≈øting of ≈øucce≈ø≈øes be a principle part in all their papers and ≈øo in this, Yet it is not intended (they ≈øay) to be very particular in mentioning the State of the affairs of this Commonwealth, as it ≈øtood when, oppre≈ø≈øed by a Tyrant, they were nece≈ø≈øitated to fly to Armes, for defence of their Lives and E≈øtates, becau≈øe in Parliament they did but a≈ø≈øert, and de≈øire the ≈øetling of their ju≈øt and Native liberties. When over particulars are mentioned of the State of
affaires in England in the time of the late King, their Faithle≈ø≈øe and bloody proceedings mu≈øt more cleerly be manife≈øt. And its proofe to all rea≈øonable men of a re≈øolved continuance in wicked undertakings, that they call the King a Tyrant, when not onely the mildne≈ø≈øe of his nature, and Moderation of his privat and publique Actions, but the Peace and Pro≈øperity of the People was ≈øo univer≈øally knowne to ≈øtrangers, and when in all that peevi≈øh di≈øcontent, or Traiterous malice could offer again≈øt him, there was no one Act in its nature and ≈øub≈øtance Oppre≈ø≈øion, but ≈øuch only, as were pretended might not be done by the King out of Parliament, and no one of the≈øe was done by the King, Regi√¢ manu, (with the Kingly power) but left to the ordinary Mini≈øters of Law, and Ju≈øtice to decide in point of right, and execute accordingly; but the≈øe men knowing how odious their Actions are, ≈øeeke a cover from reproachfull appellations upon the King, as if any could entertaine a prejudice by mi≈ønaming per≈øons, or Actions, and if it were Tyranny for the King to do an Action out of Parliament, which he was advi≈øed by the Judges of law he ju≈øtly might: how impudent are the≈øe men to reduce it? For where is the Parliament Authority for their va≈øt levies of mony, Murder of the King, and the impo≈øing Lawes upon the people? Can a few per≈øons of the Lower Hou≈øe, ≈øcarce the tenth part of the whole, by violence totally aboli≈øh both Hou≈øes, and doe all Acts that belonged to the whole? And yet they per≈øwade the world they are beleeved in ≈øuch extravagant untruths. There need nothing be more ≈øaid how cau≈øele≈øly the Rebells of England tooke Armes again≈øt the King. And if Rebells may pretend defence of their per≈øons again≈øt Soveraigne power, Malefactors will never want a ju≈øtification, when force is u≈øed to bring them to Ju≈øtice. And is it one of the ju≈øt and native liberties of the Engli≈øh nation, that the members of Parliament in the Lower Hou≈øe being five hundred, forty of the≈øe may drive out the re≈øt, and doe what they plea≈øe? this is the pre≈øent ca≈øe. But if we looke back, is it the liberty of England to be without a King, or to be ≈øubject to the power of one another, & have no recour≈øe to their Prince for redre≈ø≈øe! Is it the liberty of England, that a rabble of the City of London or an Army ≈øhall oppre≈ø≈øe the Parliament and propound laws to oblige the whol Kingdom? Is it the liberty of England to exclude the King from making of laws, or governing the Militia? But they that are not a≈øhamed to act, yet ≈øeeme loath to ≈øpeak the things they doe. The ≈øeizing the Kings forts and navy, rai≈øing force again≈øt him and both Hou≈øes of Parliament, puni≈øhing Judges for doing their
duty, and delivering their opinions in open Courts, again≈øt ≈øedition, licencing all lewd ≈øectaries and di≈øturbers of Government are only a≈ø≈øerting and de≈øire of ≈øetling ju≈øt and native liberties. Thus they call their murders Ju≈øtice, their robberies Reparation of Wrongs; And their per≈øecution of the King from one end of the Kingdome to the other, the defence of their lives and E≈øtates. Its well ≈øeene, that tho≈øe men are the God of Gods anger upon the three Kingdoms, but they vainly flatter them≈øelvs to think that any beleeve it a ble≈ø≈øing of God as they a≈ø≈øume it, or that the≈øe wonders in ≈øo many ≈øignal battells, or that ≈øeries of providence was either in favour to them or their cau≈øe, and ≈øuch pre≈øumptuous pretences declare of what ≈øpirit men are, that they take up the language of Senacharib, who came not without God again≈øt Jeru≈øalem, and of the Turk, that attributes all his ≈øucce≈ø≈øes again≈øt the Chri≈øtians to the power of his fal≈øe Prophet. And tho≈øe men that in their writings again≈øt the King, u≈øed the name of the whole Kingdom on their part, and the ≈ømall ≈øtrength of the King, now tells us of an handfull of men that were faithfull to the cau≈øe, even ≈øo faithfull, that they fir≈øt brake allegeance to their King, and then all fidelity to men. What they ≈øaid in this clau≈øe they ≈øay, was not intended to be mentioned, and indeed it no way concerned their pre≈øent controver≈øie with the United Provinces, unle≈ø≈øe they thought to ≈øcare all men by recounting their own Actions. But they proceed to ≈øay, neither is that indeavour to divide them in the memorable yeare of forty eight to be omitted. Surely the one might have been omitted as well as the other was not intended, for it hath nothing proper to their Declaration, unle≈ø≈øe they meant to make their owne ≈øtory; And they very un≈øea≈øonably mention the endeavour to divide them, when they were formerly divided, and the divi≈øion ≈øtill continued, and them≈øelves not onely endeavoured, but effected it, rej ‚Ä¢ cting both Scots and Presbyterian; Was not the new modell and change of the Generall their Act? And was not their divi≈øion further acted by purging the Hou≈øe, and change of the Government?

Nor can they admit the great preparation against this Nation in the yeare, 1650. And what is all this to the United Provinces? And can they think any man believs, that preparations to a≈ø≈øi ‚Ä¢ t the King, di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them of their u≈øurpation, and re≈øtore the Nation to its ju≈øt Rights, are preparations again≈øt the Nation? but this is the common ≈øtile of them Declarations.

This (they ≈øay) nece≈ø≈øitated their proceedings in Scotland, being refu≈øed ≈øatisfaction for forepa≈øt wrongs, and denyed a≈ø≈øurance of peace from
them, who had received the declared Enemy of the Commonwealth from the ∆≤nited provinces. Their guilt, and malice nece≈ø≈øitated their proceedings; for the Scots were obliged to receive their lawfull King, and will any accu≈øe Subject, for fidelity and obedience to their King, but ≈øuch as hate all piety and truth? but what were tho≈øe forepa≈øt wrongs? They had agreed with the Scots after the engagement of forty eight, which was the wrong pretended, and nothing can be a≈ø≈øurance of peace to them, but a totall abdication of Loyalty, and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the new Republican power of England. And it is their pretence of inva≈øion to have ≈øatisfaction upon mens e≈øtates, and ≈øecurity by en≈ølaving their per≈øons. The Scots were unhappily m ‚Ä¢ ≈øled in in their connection with the Engli≈øh in their Rebellion again≈øt the King, and found the reward of it from tho≈øe they a≈ø≈øi ‚Ä¢ ted; And yet after they di≈øcerned the mi≈øchievous con≈øequents of their undertaking upon their owne Nation, continued yet jealou≈øies of one another, and while they feared that, which might never happen, they ≈øuffered that, which they ≈øaw was unavoidably falling on them, the power of the Engli≈øh Rebells; And while ≈øome would act alone, and had feare of the event of a victory if they got it, betrayed all to the common Enemy. And what if they received the King from tho≈øe Provinces? Did he not come through the Dominions of the Kings of France & Spaine? And what was the mi≈øchievous contrivement, that was hatched there again≈øt England? Doubtle≈ø≈øe if the contrivement were to bring in the King, it had been happy for England if it had taken effect But what is this to the United Provinces, if Strangers and Allies pa≈ø≈øe through their Countrey? But they ≈øay, their Enemies had much open and ≈øecret a≈ø≈øi≈øtance by the Intere≈øt of the Prince of Orange; and others. And what law, or convention was there again≈øt it? had the United Provinces any League with England be≈øides what was made with the late King? and when their Ally dyes, mu≈øt they quit all friend≈øhip to his heire?

They ≈øay, it was a time, when the Prince, and his adherents were contriving as is mo≈øt probable, to erect a Tyranny upon the≈øe Countryes, of which he mi≈ø≈øed but narrowly, e≈øpecially in his attempt upon Am≈øterdam, which things they ≈øay are better knowne there then heere, and are not the purpo≈øe of this Declaration. But it was purpo≈øely ≈øet in to ≈øcatter jealou≈øi ‚Ä¢ s in their Provinces, and divide th ‚Ä¢ ir affections, & endeavours again≈øt the malitious attempts of this common Enemy. The differences ari≈øing touching the attempt upon Am≈øterdam were prudently compo≈øed and buryed by the States Provinces,
and no man will mea≈øure intentions by the malitious invectives of an Enemy, that contrives to effect that, which he ≈øaies another inrended. Tyrany is judged by the ≈øence, not by the fancy. But wi≈øemen will not by the apprehon≈øion of pa≈øt or remote dangers make way for pre≈øent. They ≈øay it is not plea≈øant to remember the cruel and bloudy bu≈øine≈øs of Amboina, for which no ≈øatisfaction hath bin given though often demanded. But never by them, when they ≈øent their Agents Amba≈ø≈øadors to treat, whereof they ≈øpeak afterwards; And if it were not plea≈øant to them, they would rather have endeavoured ≈øatisfaction when they treated, then repetition when they were in ho≈øtility.

Now they come to unkindne≈ø≈øes received, that the Parliament ≈øent a Re≈øident to the States General, who refu≈øed to receive him. The rea≈øon is very apparent. The Parliament never had ≈øent any Re≈øident, neither was any ≈øuch Authority acknowledged by forreign States; And its a known Trea≈øon for the per≈øons in Parliament to doe ≈øuch an Act. Be≈øides the United Provinces were in league and amity with the King. The Parliament, or ≈øuch, as called them≈øelves ≈øo, had not then renounced the Kingly Title, and ≈øtill allowed the Oaths of Allegeance, and Supremacy to the King, and therefore their Re≈øident was ill ≈øent, and ju≈øtly refu≈øed. But they think this amounts to an unkindne≈øs, ≈øince it proceeded from their affection to the ∆≤nited Provinces, the e≈øtabli≈øhment of liberty & advantage of traffique, and strength to both. Their affections are doubtles ≈øuch, as are u≈øuall between neer and potent Republiques, e≈øpecially where the advantages of traffique are the common aim of both, which not only creates emulations, but nece≈ø≈øarily makes continued differences till one be de≈øtroyed; and thence proceeded the Judgement of Qu. Elizabeth, who concluded that the United Provinces mu≈øt in wi≈ødome de≈øire the ≈øtability of the Engli≈øh Monarchy, where by the≈øe ruptures might be prevented, & the Crown of England had greater a≈ø≈øurance of the≈øe Provinces in the Government they were under, then if they had bin under a Prince, when new Alliances and engagements would continually change the affections and Councels of the Prince, but when the≈øe men ≈øent their Re≈øident, their affections were to their own intere≈øt, and they ≈øought to gain reputation by having a Re≈øident received, and to dimini≈øh the Kingly power abroad

But the rea≈øon above al (they ≈øay) was the advancement of the true Prote≈øtant Religion, which both profe≈øs, and which in humane probability would receive the greate≈øt growth by their friend≈øhip. The State of the United Provinces did not think, that England profe≈ø≈øed not the true Prote≈øtant
Religion in the time of Queen Elizabeth, and the Kings ≈øince, but the Religion tho≈øe new Governours profe≈ø≈øe, no true Prote≈øtant will own for his, no one Church e≈øtabli≈øhed in any e≈øtate concurring with them; And as one chief Article in their Religion is upon their own private Authority to rob their neighbours and kill their Kings: ≈øo their doctrine and practice hath been a great ≈øcandall to the Prote≈øtant Religion, wherof they pretend to be. Their profe≈ø≈øed opinions are de≈øtructive to humane ≈øociety, di≈øclaiming all ≈øubjection to Civil Governors, or Eccle≈øia≈øticall Synods, further then their private opinions concur with them, and maintaine not onely the reproaches of Rulers, but violence again≈øt them, if in their judgement they de≈øerve puni≈øhment to death, and this tho≈øe men would have to be the true Prote≈øtant Religion, and their affection to the Prote≈øtant Religion is ≈øeene in their cruelty to the Prote≈øtants of England.

Next they ob≈øerved in ≈øome of the Governors, and people of tho≈øe Countries an affection to this cau≈øe, and expre≈ø≈øed by them in their free contribution for the poore Prote≈øtants in Ireland. It is far from a probability, that any affected their cau≈øe, becau≈øe they contributed to the poore Prote≈øtants of Ireland. Them≈øelves well know, that very many contributed to the poore Prote≈øtants of Ireland, that hated the Rebellion, that occa≈øioned it; & if any man hated the Iri≈øh Rebellion, he mu≈øt from the ≈øame grounds have dete≈øtation of a greater and more guilty, which followed in England; And the ≈øuffering Prote≈øtants in England are more in number, and for quality more eminent then tho≈øe in Ireland, and that of England hath had more barbarous effects, and is more incapable of excu≈øe, that of Ireland pretending difference of Nation and Religion, this of England pretending the ≈øame Religion, as they were of the ≈øame Nation; And its too well knowne both at home, & abroad how many tho≈øe in England have robbed of their E≈øtates, that not only contributed to the reliefe of the poor Prote≈øtants of Ireland, but hazarded their lives in that cau≈øe. And ≈øuch, as in the beginning of the troubles in England extended compa≈ø≈øion to the poor Prote≈øtants of Ireland, di≈øcerned not the mercile≈ø≈øe di≈øpo≈øition of tho≈øe men, that then governed affaires in England, who never did one Act in order to their relief, but made u≈øe of their ≈øufferings to reproach the King; And by hypocriticall motions of other men to Charity ≈øought an opinion of Zeal to them≈øelves, and means to carry on the war in England again≈øt the King; And tho≈øe great ≈øummes, that were given to the reliefe of Ireland they converted to the maintenance of their own Rebellion in
England; and as many in the≈øe Provinces find the error they were in touching the integrity of the Reformers in England: So their Actions for the reliefe of the poor Prote≈øtents in Ireland will not prove, that they hated Rebellion le≈ø≈øe in tho≈øe, that profe≈ø≈øe the Prote≈øtant Religion then the Popi≈øh.

They joyned (they ≈øay) with their Re≈øident a worthy per≈øon Dr. Dori≈ølaus, who was barbarou≈øly, and openly murthered at the Hague the place of re≈øidence of the States General, of who≈øe a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øination the world will judge as of an Action mo≈øt abhorred again≈øt all Rules of nationall intercour≈øe, and humanity, and how little was done to attach the murtherers mu≈øt here be remembred. The quality of Dr. Dori≈ølaus is chiefly known by their imployment of him in forming their proceedings again≈øt their King to a ≈øtile of law and this negotiation they mention, which latter they might out of fore≈øight, knowing how odious the man was to the world abroad, have forborne, and have ≈øent one not ≈øo deeply died in that bloud, for what care ≈øoever-≈øtates take to re≈øtrain, and puni≈øh outward Actions, they cannot take away the univer≈øall indignation of a people again≈øt unnaturall and barbarous villanies. But Dori≈ølaus was killed in an hou≈øe ≈øuddenly, which, though in the place of re≈øidence of the States Generall, tho≈øe complainers cannot pretend it in the power of the States Generall to have prevented, and they cannot intend the breach of all Rules of intercour≈øe, or humanity in that Act by the States, though they di≈øplay the fact with ≈øuch colours. They need not be told, that the Rules of intercour≈øe, and humanity allow no protection to common robbers, and enemies of humane ≈øociety; And tho≈øe men, that think the world ≈øo ready to make the Judgement they like, of this fact upon Dori≈ølaus, ≈øee not the Judgement them≈øelves given of their own a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øination, and therein the Crime of Dori≈ølaus in the murder of the King: was not every man as much a Magi≈øtrate to execute Dori≈ølaus as they their King? And the Me≈ø≈øengers of common de≈øtroyers cannot be accounted publique Mini≈øters, but by whom they are acknowledged for ≈øuch. But if ≈øuch, as did the fact were unknown to the States General, how could they attach them, or if they were gone out of their Territories though they were often called on? And why this mu≈øt be here remembred as a nationall Injury is not vi≈øible to any, but to ≈øhew the re≈øolution of the≈øe Governours to quarrel with the United Provinces, there having never bin a deniall of Ju≈øtice, and legall proceedings?

The States (they ≈øay) ≈øent the Lords Borele, Renzwo, and Joachimi Amba≈ø≈øadours in the time of the late troubles, pretending all good offices, which
proved a corre≈øpondence with the Enemy, and a means of a≈ø≈øi≈øting them again≈øt tho≈øe, to whom they were ≈øent, this with reproaches by them ca≈øt upon the Parliament was the work of the≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours. It was a friendly and worthy Action of the States of the≈øe Provinces to ≈øeek the compo≈øing of the troubles in England, and to interpo≈øe their Councel, and mediation in a work ≈øo becomming their Alliance; And it was no more then Ju≈øtice to the King to corre≈øpond with him, and the≈øe men of We≈øtmin≈øter mu≈øt be remembred, that at this time they had not declared the King an Enemy, but they fought again≈øt evil Councellours, and they took up Arms for King, and Parliament, their party was not impudent enough then to avow the Titles they have ≈øince taken up. They well know the≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours were ≈øent to the King and though thye interceded with them, that called them≈øelves Parliament, it was in that manner as Emba≈ø≈øadours addre≈ø≈øe them≈øelves to treat with the Mini≈øters of Princes, to whom they are ≈øent; And the≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours then found what was doubtfull to many before, that the men then in ho≈øtility under the name of Parliament had abu≈øed the world with a pretence of nece≈ø≈øity to take Armes for defence of Religion and lawes, ≈øeeking only power to them≈øelues, and an alteration of Religion and law, and that they had ob≈øtinately refu≈øed all the gracious offers of the King, and his de≈øires of peace, and the≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours were bound in honour and fidelity to deal uprightly in their negotiation, & to declare where the binderances of peace lay; And if the actions of the then pretended Parliament were reproachfull to them≈øelves, they cannot blame the Emba≈ø≈øad ours for a faithfull report of them, & this was very far from making them lyable by the practice of nations to puni≈øhment, or reproof; and it ≈øtood not with the affairs of the then Rebels in England to offer incivility to tho≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours, though they wanted not an inclination to it; & tho≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours need not be carefull to an≈øwer for ≈øuch an Action, wherein they had cleere rea≈øon, and the warrant of their ≈øuperiours, to whom the complainers di≈øcovered the iniquity of their cau≈øe by ≈øo unju≈øt an exception.

They come now to the ≈øolemn Emba≈ø≈øy they ≈øent the States, which (they ≈øay) was in a time when there was much le≈øs cau≈øe to apply to the States for any need the Parliament had of their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, for that England was wholly in their power, mo≈øt of the Towns & Cities in Ireland, the affairs of Scotland not unpro≈øperous. But whoever took notice of the affairs then, knew very well they had neede of the forbearance of the United Provinces
from engaging again≈øt them which had they then acted, its probably they had prevented the progre≈øs of their victories, and rendred them liable to their demerits; And what the men of We≈øtmin≈øter did in that Emba≈ø≈øy was in order to their own affairs, not out of any priciples of affection to the Proty≈øtant Intere≈øt or common good. They endeavoured to draw the United Provinces into their own guilt by the league they propounded, ≈øo as the≈øe Provinces mu≈øt have ≈øupported their u≈øurpation, and have drawn on them the infamy of Murdering the King and all the former Actions, whereby that u≈øurpation was effected. Though Princes and States for the peace of their people ≈øometimes enter into leagues for comerce, with ≈øuch, who by wicked attempts have obteined the power of States, yet neither Religion nor civill Ju≈øtice permit defence of unju≈øt power; And when tho≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours di≈øcerned that the United Provinces could not be drawn into a ≈øcandalous league, then they de≈øerted the pro≈øecution; And the≈øe tenders, which their Emba≈ø≈øadours were impowered to make, that would have demon≈øtrated the affection of the≈øe in England to the good People of the United Provinces the ≈øame as to them≈øelves, ≈øufficiently demon≈øtrate their affection to the people of the≈øe Provinces to be only for them≈øelves; And the Priviledges they tendred to them were to divide them from their own State to a dependance on a forreign kindne≈øs, and was of the ≈øame ≈øtamp with this hypocriticall profe≈ø≈øion to the good people of the≈øe Provinces, the≈øe good people being in their ≈øen≈øe ≈øuch, as would be ≈øeduced again≈øt their Country by their attempts, ≈øuch being their dealing with Scots pretending rather private enmity again≈øt ≈øome per≈øons, then Dominion over all, which was ≈øo apparently their De≈øign, as it will be the ≈øhame of any, that ≈øhall hereafter pretend ignorance of it. They ≈øay the Emba≈ø≈øy was rendred of no effect becau≈øe the Emba≈ø≈øadours were unheartily, and dilatorily dealt with. But the true rea≈øon was, that the≈øe Ma≈øters had in≈øtructed their Emba≈ø≈øadours to make no agreement without the ab≈øolute ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of the≈øe Provinces to them. If their Emba≈ø≈øadours were un≈øafe in their per≈øons, it was not by any neglect of the States of the United Provinces, who placed a ≈øufficient guard about them, & puni≈øhed ≈øuch as offered indignities to them, and if their Emba≈ø≈øadours concealed it, they dealt unfaithfully with their ≈øuperiours, and unju≈øtly with them they were ≈øent to: And when it appeared the States of the United Provinces would not partake in the guilt of that blood, and u≈øurpation with the≈øe Ma≈øters in England, the Emba≈ø≈øadours were recalled home.

That the States Generall ≈øent not an Emba≈ø≈øy till after the defeat at Worce≈øter is true, and the willingne≈øs and affectection with which it was received, doth te≈øtifie for the Engli≈øh part, they ≈øtood fixed to their former Principles, which were to ≈øerve them≈øelves of the power, and Intere≈øt of the vinced Provinces; for to prepare for the Emba≈ø≈øadours entertainment, they had made an Act as they call it, that no commodities ≈øhould be brought into England by any forraign ve≈ø≈øels, but ≈øuch as were of the growth of that Country, to which ≈øuch ve≈ø≈øell belonged, which tooke away that traffique, and intercour≈øe, which was in all ages continued betweene the nations, and had no other ≈øcope but to interrupt the trade of the≈øe Provinces: And as this Act te≈øt ‚Ä¢ fies what principles they went in to de≈øtroy the trade, and navall ≈øtrength of the United Provinces, ≈øo they being the ≈øame they had in their former proceedings, and ≈øending their Emba≈ø≈øy, they vainly pretend affection to Religion, Liberty, or amity with this Country, while they expre≈ø≈øe a malicious De≈øign to en≈ølave, or de≈øtroy it from their fir≈øt Treaty with them.

They finde fault that in the Treaty the States Amba≈ø≈øadours evaded po≈ø≈øitive demands in things not of harde≈øt re≈øolution with allegations of want of power, though their Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øhewed no ≈øuch re≈øtraint. The age of the≈øe mens rule in England may be read in the≈øe frivolous objections. Though Emba≈ø≈øadors have an ab≈øolut commi≈ø≈øion, are they not tyed to in≈øtructions? And are there not particular laws, & cu≈øtomes in States, that limit Emba≈ø≈øadours, and yet not expre≈ø≈øed in their Commi≈ø≈øion? But whence comes the Allegation of want of power to be an eva≈øion? And becau≈øe the Provincial States mu≈øt be a≈ø≈øembled before an≈øwers could be had, it gave ≈ømall grounds of any real intendment of a firm peace, and amity. It was a firm ground of aver≈øion to peace in tho≈øe of England, that they were po≈øitive in ≈øuch demands, as mu≈øt enforce the meeting of the Provinciall States to give a re≈øolution. Upon the comming of the Emba≈ø≈øadours of the States General into England, its well knowne what licence was taken by mean people to abu≈øe them: And to let them know what they mu≈øt tru≈øt to, a Treati≈øe is compo≈øed, & publi≈øhed of the bu≈øine≈øs of Amboina, which had re≈øted for ≈øo many years, and till then unmentioned by tho≈øe affectionate ≈øeekers of amity with the United Provinces. Herein they provoke the people to a≈ø≈øume an hatred of the≈øe Provinces, & to ≈øeek revenge for an Act ≈øo long pa≈ø≈øed. If they had intended amity, or thought a ≈øtrict Alliance with the≈øe Provinces nece≈ø≈øary, why would they renew the memory of old differences, or fix an aver≈øion in the people to tho≈øe, with whom they treated for peace?
This might have bin a proper work after a treaty broken, but to make ≈øuch a narration the Prologue to a Treaty, is a ≈øure ground, that no peace was intended, but ≈øuch, as force and terrour could extort; And that ≈øuch prop≈øitions mu≈øt be granted to obtein it as a conquered people only mu≈øt ≈øubmit to, and they mu≈øt needs give way to the exerci≈øe of the peoples licence, and hatred that u≈øed the means to work it in them. And this de≈øigne of the Rulers being known it was ≈øoon pro≈øecuted, their ordinary Agents, the Preachers and compo≈øers of Gazetts, and Almanacks publi≈øhed it to the world, and from thence came the≈øe predictions of their South ≈øayers of the destruction of Holland; And the≈øe di≈øcuour≈øes of their Politiques of ≈øubjecting ≈øuch powers, as might be prejudiciall to the new Babell they had rai≈øed in England, and therefore the United Provinces being able to do them harm, they mu≈øt have the≈øe Countries in ≈øuch a Chaine, as may draw them that way onely where tho≈øe new Rulers ≈øhall move, and like formes of Govenment are no more to them then the brotherhood of Scotland. It cannot be pre≈øumed, that the ≈øervants ≈øpeak other than their Ma≈øters ≈øen≈øe; And if it had bin contrary, it would have appeared in their re≈øtraint, or puni≈øhment; And the≈øe Rulers vainely offer an exception of dilatorine≈ø≈øe on the part of the United Provinces when there were ≈øo many of their ≈øhips continually taken, and made prize during the Teraty, and the danger of tho≈øe Provinces mu≈øt be increa≈øed by delay, the ≈øea≈øons of their Trade, and return of their ≈øhips being known, and un≈øafe while the Treaty was unconluded.

And its will known the preparation of Shipe in England proceded tho≈øe of Holland; And though they ≈øpeak of preparations upon the notice the Emba≈ø≈øadours of the States General gave them of ≈øetting out a hundred, and fifty ≈øail of ≈øhips be≈øides the men of war abroad‚ñ™ all men know the preparations in England, and affronts received nece≈ø≈øarily occa≈øioned that care in the States Generall. But tho≈øe of England were offended that the States Generall ≈øhould defend their Merchants, which they meant to make prize of; And be≈øides the exerci≈øe of repri≈øals on the ≈øhips of the United Provinces, the grounds, on which their Commi≈ø≈øions of Repri≈øall were granted, ≈øhewed it no other then an open ho≈øtility, as that, which was to repair one, that was intercepted by the States ≈øhips carrying ≈øupplies out of England into Flanders before the peace betweene tho≈øe Countries, and the King of Spain, and others of le≈ø≈øe colour. It is ea≈øily believed, they altered not their re≈øolutions upon notice of the States prepations; But that they made Ju≈øtice, honour, and mutuall good the Rule to ≈øteere their Actions by, is incredible to any
that knew their former, or pre≈øent Actions: For is it Ju≈øtice to grant, letters of Repri≈øall upon a particular ca≈øe, unle≈ø≈øe Ju≈øtice be fir≈øt demanded for the fact and denyed? And can it ≈øtand with honour, Ju≈øtice, and mutual good to require unequal conditions, & an ab≈øolute ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion for peace? And the happy clo≈øe of the Treaty, which the≈øe: Rulers were willing to come to, appears no other but to have the United Provinces under their command: For the Accidents touching Captaine Young, and Admirall Tromp by the narrative, which the U≈øurpers of England, have publi≈øhed, the world will judge, that they ≈øought an occa≈øion again≈øt the United Provinces, and to renounce all amity with them; And their aggravation adds not weight of Argument for what they offer, for if the midde≈øt of a Treaty be con≈øiderable, why did tho≈øe men of peace continue Repri≈øalls in the midde≈øt of the ≈øame Treaty? But it is ridiculous to affirme, that the Dutch Admiral ≈øought out their Shipps in their own ≈øeas, when the trade way of tho≈øe ≈øeas is ≈øuch, as a meeting of ≈øhipps is not ea≈øily avoided; Be≈øides the peaceable demeanour of the Admirall Tromp, till he received the ≈øhots from Blake. But this is their accu≈øtomed language, their Declarations again≈øt the King being fraught with ≈øuch ≈øtuffe of making a bloudy war upon the Parliament rejecting their humble de≈øires, and of dangerous plots again≈øt the City of London, and Kingdom. But the truth of this fact is fully known, and the vanity of the≈øe declarers aggravation. And it bears full proof in it ≈øelf, that the Fleet under the command of Tromp came not purpo≈øely into the Roade of England unto their Fleet, and by all the atte≈øtations produced, he ≈øhewed no inclination to ho≈øtillity; And tho≈øe men that make al cleer on their part, like not a way of equall examination becau≈øe long & intricate, but would kave a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to their own allegations, and a ≈øatisfaction for the wroags they pretended; And they believe, that men under≈øtand not, that they could make their demands for ≈øatisfaction ≈øuch, as would take up longer debate, then that examination, and in the mean time proceed with all ho≈øtillity, which they would not forbear till that demand were ≈øatisfied; And when could the States Emba≈ø≈øadors a≈ø≈øure them≈øelves that they would determine their demands?

The rea≈øon they give for their Coun≈øel is that time being gained an addition of ≈øtrength might therwith be provided by the Dutch & from hence the re≈øolved ho≈øtility of the Rulers is evident, & that they had provided to take the Dutch unprepared, & were offended that they had a fl ‚Ä¢ et. It cannot be conceived that the≈øe Engl. Ma≈øters having propounded to have ≈øatisfaction for wrongs upon their own Allegations only without re≈øpect to what was offred to the contrary, that they would treat with ≈øuch
moderation, as ≈øuch, as treated with them ≈øhould Judge rea≈øonable, but would be ≈øole Judges of the ≈øatisfaction, as they made them≈øelves of the cau≈øe, for which they demanded it; and if they would not heare all proofes in the one ca≈øe, they were not likely to admit any rea≈øon in the other; And they might very well offer a ce≈ø≈øation of ho≈øtility upon their owne termes. They projected their ≈øatisfaction for their preparations becau≈øe the Dutch had prepared a fleete, and yet never excepted to it when notice was given them, and they enlarge this ≈øatisfaction to lo≈ø≈øes of all kinde, in the dammage of the ≈øhipps, lo≈ø≈øe of men, and the poverty of per≈øons thereby, and under tho≈øe heads who could conjecture the quantity of the ≈øatisfaction, they would thinke a fit proportion, and in the meane time no ce≈ø≈øation, and all Accidents ≈øucceeding mu≈øt be ca≈øt into the account, which might be prolonged at the plea≈øure of tho≈øe, that got by the delay; And yet tho≈øe confident men thinke it ≈øtrange, that the Lord Emba≈ø≈øadour Paw did not pur≈øue his d ‚Ä¢ ≈øire of ce≈ø≈øation, when by their an≈øwer they ≈øhewed their re≈øolution to keep it in their own power to ≈øet the time to it, and was no more then if they had an≈øwered, it ≈øhould be at their plea≈øure, and yet they are not a≈øhamed to ≈øay, it was in his own power to accompli≈øh it. Can any man think it was in his power to accompli≈øh what they would demand? And is it not a de≈øperate compliance for any State to continue treating, while ho≈øtillity is avowe ‚Ä¢ , and terms only propounded of ab≈øolute ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to avoid it? Thus the Emba≈ø≈øadours were forced to depart to pre≈øerve the honour, and ≈øafety of them≈øelves, and their Country. It ≈øeems tho≈øe Declarers think they merited by giving re≈øpect and accommodation to the Amba≈ø≈øadours: And con≈øidering their other actions, and di≈øpo≈øition, wor≈øe might have been expected, but they found it not for their pre≈øent advantage, nor doth the mention of their yeilding to re≈øpect and accommodation tend to their honour, as if it were que≈øtionable whither they ≈øhould have performed it, and during their abode they neither expected, nor found better u≈øage then the Mini≈øters of the≈øe Rulers found from the States of the United Provinces; and they had not merited that aver≈øion of the people, which was unive≈øally expre≈ø≈øed to the Mini≈øters of tho≈øe Rulers.

The Narrative by them publi≈øhed, they hold a ≈øufficient ju≈øtification of Acts of ho≈øtillity, and deteining ≈øhipps brought into their Ports without any precedent Declaration, or notice to the Emba≈ø≈øadours then in Treaty. The Narrative is of one ≈øide onely giving no an≈øwer to contrary atte≈øtations; and though it be evident to all rea≈øonable
men, that the fact was accident all and unde≈øignet by Tromp, yet this Narrative is all the rea≈øon they will give for a pre≈øent ho≈øtility, neither could any pro≈øecution be looked for before the ca≈øe were fully examined, where friend≈øhip was ≈øo confidenly profe≈ø≈øed. Neither had their forbearance been laying downe of them≈øelves at the feete of any. But the ≈øpeedy feirce pur≈øuit ≈øhewes not a ≈øudden pa≈ø≈øion, but a long premeditated Coun≈øell for the oppre≈ø≈øion of the United Provinces, and de≈øtroying their trade, and ≈øtrength by ≈øea, and yet ≈øo ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe are they to call this proceeding their owne defence, and if they had done contrary, it had been again≈øt the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them, few men thinke the Actions of the≈øe Declarers agreeable to any rules, whereby nations or ≈øingle per≈øons are governed, and breach of tru≈øt is of no regard with them, for there was not any tru≈øt repo≈øed in them by King, or people, but what they have mo≈øt perfidiou≈øly broken; that tru≈øt, which was repo≈øed in them as ≈øubjects, whereto they were bound by Religion, Law, and nature, they have fal≈øified to their King and Countrey. They were called by the Kings writ, and by law incapable of any place in Parliament, till they had taken the oaths of Allegeance, and Supremacy. They were tru≈øted to petition the King, and offer their Councell, they de≈øtroy the King in≈øteede of petitioning, make laws, and change the Government in de≈øpight of the tru≈øt they pretend to regard. If we examine their Doctrines, they maintai ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them≈øelves not bound to oaths longer then they think fit. If we look upon their proceedings, they have acted accordingly, breaking all oaths, and promi≈øes, the tru≈øt, whereon depends humane ≈øociety, a≈ø≈øerting fal≈øhood and abjuring truths. There are numerous Te≈øtimonies of all the≈øe in the Declarations and Treaties with the King, that they would make him a glorious King; that it never entred into their thought to depo≈øe him; that if they ≈øhould charge the King with any evill Action, it were contrary to the law, and the Te≈øtimony of their owne Con≈øcience; That providing for the prosperity of his Maje≈øty who prote≈øt in the pre≈øence of all ≈øeeing Deity to be the end of all our Coun≈øells; That they have nothing in their thoughts more precious next to the honour and immediate ≈øervice of God, then their ju≈øt and faithfull performance of their duty to his Maje≈øty. This being compared with their actions who can repo≈øe tru≈øt in them; Be≈øides, they are not tru≈øted by the Kingdom, and tho≈øe few of them that were depuzed by particular places were not tru≈øted to rule, but they now tiranize, and trample on ≈øuch, as at fir≈øt tru≈øted them; and comparing their Actions towards the united Provinces, and their words
we may Judge they are not changed in their principles, for they ≈øay by tho≈øe proceedings it will be more then evident with what affection, and con≈øtancy the Parliament have laboured for the friend ≈øh of he United Provinces, how carefully they avoided all differences, and occa≈øions of a warre between the nations, though all ≈øuch overtures of amity, and neere≈øt alliance having been rejected. In the beginning of the wicked Rebellion in England, not only the common people at home, but ≈øtrangers were much mi≈øtaken of the condition and intention of tho≈øe, that made them≈øelves a party again≈øt the King, ma ‚Ä¢ y per≈øwading them≈øelves, that the prevalent party in Parliament had the ≈øame ≈øincerity in their purpo≈øes, which they profe≈ø≈øed in their ≈øpeeches, and papers. But ≈øuch, as were then deceived, ≈øee the di≈øcovery of their e ‚Ä¢ rour, and that tho≈øe pretences of Religion, Law, and Loyalty were only ≈ønares, whereby they were ≈øeduced to their owne ruine: And though the fi ‚Ä¢ ≈øt lo≈ø≈øe lighted on the King, and his Loyall ≈øubjects, the whole Kingdome hath ≈øelt the ≈øcourge of that credulity: And while ≈øome were mi≈øled, and others re≈øted ≈øecure, as unconcerned, not fore≈øeeing the con≈øequents of popular conte≈øts with Soveraignty, the whole are brought under the Tyrannicall power of a few contemptible per≈øons: And ≈øuch, as with dry eyes beheld the ≈øufferings of the King and his party, finde the ≈øame fince at their owne doores: And ≈øuch, as acted under the name of Parliament again≈øt the King are now oppre≈ø≈øed under the ≈øame pretence, which them≈øelves u≈øed, they per≈øwading men they were the Parliament, though the King and the greate≈øt part of the Lords, and a great number of the Commons were forced away, and the remaining party overawed by the City Tumults and Army, now groane under this new power, that call them≈øelves a Parliament, though the King be murdered, the Lords hou≈øe ≈øhut up, the greate≈øt part of the Commons impri≈øoned, and expelled. And onely a few per≈øons ≈øit, as a Lower Hou≈øe without any colour of Law. The neglect of oppo≈øition to growing evills is often too late repented, and ≈øuch, as doubted not what hath hapned in England, may now ≈øee, that wickedne≈ø≈øe puts no bounds to it ≈øelfe. It mu≈øt be re≈øi≈øtance, from without, not the inward inclination that mu≈øt re≈øtraine it; And where men have ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and an opinion of ≈øtrength, they re≈øt not at a ≈øtay e≈øpecially new gained powers, and the Example of th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe per≈øons is no le≈ø≈øe dangerous, then their power. Princes and States are cheifely concerned in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing ≈øuch pernicious Mon≈øters, who≈øe opinions and De≈øignes are the ≈øubver≈øion of Rulers, and draw with them the mi≈øery of the people, who mu≈øt fall into confu≈øion and ≈ølavery. If their de≈øigne take upon the United Provinces, it may be ea≈øily conjectured what their attempts will be next. And affection to an oppre≈ø≈øed King, and Ally, amity to the Engli≈øh nation, ≈øecurity to Religion and commerce, call for a conjunction of the hearts and hands of all Chri≈øtian Kings and States again≈øt tho≈øe common Enemyes of mankind.
